summary: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) is a chronic blood cancer originating in the bone marrow, characterized by the overproduction of abnormal lymphocytes. These abnormal cells displace healthy blood cells, leading to symptoms such as infection, anemia, and easy bleeding. It primarily affects adults, especially those over 50, and can spread to other body parts.
causes: Genetic changes in bone marrow cells
Chromosomal translocations (general to hematologic malignancies, arising from aberrant DNA double-strand break repair)
risk_factors: Family history of CLL or other blood and bone marrow diseases
Exposure to certain chemicals (e.g., Agent Orange)
symptoms: Pain or feeling of fullness below the ribs
diagnosis: Blood chemistry tests (e.g., basic metabolic panel, comprehensive metabolic panel, kidney function tests, liver function tests, electrolyte panel)
Flow cytometry tests (on blood, bone marrow, or other tissue)
Genetic tests (for gene and chromosome changes)
